awd_titl_txt: Impacts of STEM Experiences on Informal STEM Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. Informal STEM educational activities have proliferated widely in the US over the last 20 years.  Additional research will further validate the long-term benefits of this mode of learning. Thus, elaborating the multitude of variables in informal learning and how those variables can be used for individual learning is yet to be defined for the circumstances of the learners. Thus, the primary objective of this work is to produce robust and detailed evidence to help shape both practice and policy for informal STEM learning in a broad array of common circumstances such as rural, urban, varying economic situations, and unique characteristics and cultures of citizen groups. Rather than pursuing a universal model of informal learning, the principal investigator will develop a series of comprehensive models that will support learning in informal environments for various demographic groups.

The research will undertake a longitudinal mixed-methods approach of Out of School Time/informal STEM experiences over a five-year time span of data collection for youth ages 9-19 in urban, suburban, town, and rural communities. The evidence base will include data on youth experiences of informal STEM, factors that exert an influence on participation in informal STEM, the impact of participation on choices about educational pathways and careers, and preferences for particular types of learning activities. The quantitative data will include youth surveys, program details (e.g. duration of program, length of each program session, youth/facilitator ratio, etc.), and demographics. The qualitative data will include on-site informal interviews with youth and facilitators, and program documentation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

Project EXPLORE2 (NSF DRL 1811265)

Robert H. Tai, Ed.D., PI, University of Virginia

Katherine P. Danny, Ph.D., Co-PI, Virginia Commonwealth University

Ji Hoon Ryoo, Ph.D., Co-PI, Yonsei University

 

The following research studies have contributed to the knowledge-based related to the fields of youth STEM learning engagement and STEM workforce development.

 

Tai, Robert H. and Ryoo, Ji Hoon and Mitchell, Claire E. and Kong, Xiaoqing and Skeeles-Worley, Angela and Almarode, John T. and Maltese, Adam V. and Dabney, Katherine P.. (2021). Gauging Informal STEM Youth Program Impact: A Conceptual Framework and a Measurement Instrument.  Journal of Youth Development. 16  (4) 103 - 133. doi: https://doi.org/10.5195/jyd.2021.981

This study examined a new instrument for measuring youth program impact based on youth engagement in seven different types of learning activities. The FOCIS survey is based on an original conceptual model take turns toward youth engagement in seven different activities common in STEM-focused learning. These seven different learning activities are: 1) collaborating, 2) competing, 3) making/creating, 4) discovering, 5) performing, 6) teaching, and 7) caretaking. FOCIS examined youth emotional engagement in these seven different learning activities.   

 

 

Ryoo, J. H., Tai, R. H., & Skeeles-Worley, A. D. (2020). Examination of Longitudinal Invariance on a Framework for Observing and Categorizing Instructional Strategies, Research in Science Education. 50(2), 489 – 504.  https://doi.org/10.1007/s11165-018-9698-7.  

This study examined the longitudinal invariance of the FOCIS instrument using longitudinal data collected from multiple cohorts of youth across numerous grade levels. The study found that youth responses to FOCIS survey instrument questions across the seven different learning activities were stable across four waves of survey implementations spanning two years. 

 

Tai, Robert H. and Ryoo, Ji Hoon and Skeeles-Worley, Angela and Dabney, Katherine P. and Almarode, John T. and Maltese, Adam V.. (2022). (Re-)Designing a measure of student’s attitudes toward science: A longitudinal psychometric approach.  International Journal of STEM Education. 9  (1)   doi: https://doi.org/10.1186/s40594-022-00332-4

This study examined the viability of a streamlined version of the modified attitudes towards science inventory (mATSI) described by Weinburgh & Steele (2000). This work discovered that the streamlined version was both reliable and exhibited stable psychometric properties consistent with the original mATSI. 

 

Xia, Xin and Bentley, Lillian_R and Fan, Xitao and Tai, Robert_H. (2024). STEM Outside of School: a Meta-Analysis of the Effects of Informal Science Education on Students' Interests and Attitudes for STEM.  International Journal of Science and Mathematics Education. doi: https://doi.org/10.1007/s10763-024-10504-z 

This article demonstrated how informal science education programs, such as science camps, museums, and after-school activities, positively impact students' interest and attitudes toward STEM. The meta-analysis revealed that, overall, these out-of-school programs foster students’ interests and attitudes toward STEM subjects. It highlighted the potential of informal science education programs to support long-term interest in STEM careers. 

 

Xia, Xin and Tai, Robert H. (2024). Using the Partial Credit Model and Rasch Model to Examine the FOCIS Survey.  IAFOR International Conference on Education official conference proceedings. doi: https://doi.org/10.22492/issn.2189-1036.2024.53 

This article evaluated the effectiveness of the Framework for Observing and Categorizing Instructional Strategies (FOCIS) survey, which assesses students' preferences for learning activities used in science instruction. Through Item Response Theory, the study confirmed that the FOCIS survey encompasses seven dimensions. 

 

Tai, Robert H and Bentley, Lillian R and Xia, Xin and Sitt, Jason M and Fankhauser, Sarah C and Chicas-Mosier, Ana M and Monteith, Barnas G. (2024). An Examination of the Use of Large Language Models to Aid Analysis of Textual Data.  International Journal of Qualitative Methods. 23.  doi: https://doi.org/10.1177/16094069241231168

This study developed a protocol for using generative artificial intelligence to provide confirmatory analysis for coding assignments made by qualitative researchers analyzing narrative interview data. The technique allows researchers to quantify the level of confidence in their assignment of codes to particular quotations from interviews.

 

Xin Xia & Robert H. Tai, (2024). Exploring The Association of Student Perceptions of Their Teachers' Science Instruction and Emotional Engagement and The Variance between Grade Level. This study identified the association between students’ perceptions of science instruction and their emotional engagement. A sample of 6465 students from 25 schools participated in the study. This study showed that students in higher grades have significantly lower emotional engagement compared to third-grade students. Similarly, students in higher grades have significantly lower values on perceptions of science instruction of interesting science and understandable science decrease compared to third grade.

 

Robert H. Tai, Ji Hoon Ryoo, Katherine P. Dabney, Xin Xia, John T. Almarode, & Adam V. Maltese (2024). An Accelerated Longitudinal Design Study Examining Emotional Engagement toward Learning Science from Grades 3 through 12.  The results show an unambiguous decline in emotional engagement among students toward learning school science. The steep decline in emotional engagement appears to begin in grade 3 with average emotional engagement crossing over to negative values by grade 9 before returning to ambivalent levels in grade 10.

 


Last Modified: 10/18/2024
Modified by: Robert H Tai
